comment: It's become a go-to for me at a nice price point. More citrus and spice comes through with the longer aging and higher rye while still having a nice sweetness. Lingers kindly on the nose  without much of a burn. Very nice chilled or as an old fashioned
Nice and sweet. Vanilla and caramel really come through. I would buy this again.

Hot, vanilla, peppery, zesty like bitter citrus, caramely underneath it all. Slight smoke and oak in the end. Pretty boozy, but as slow sipper, I like it. $21.99 per 750 ml bottle on sale. Caveat: I'm still learning lol. Cheers!
It's expensive by me so i don't often seek it out.  Nonetheless it is fantastic.  Low ethanol and burn, classic bourbon notes.  Works great in cocktails but i prefer it neat.

My favorite bourbon in it’s price range. It won’t knock your socks off but it’s reliable and dependable like your ‘98 Honda Civic that you drove 300k miles. You can find it stocked at most bars, so it’s my go-to night out sipper.

If this is the 101 level, I'm moving on to advanced classes. Smells of alcohol and straw notes. Taste is alcohol forward with new wood and straw. I can't find any complexity, just boozy notes and a fairly mild, going on bland taste. This might work in a cocktail where bourbon is more of an afterthought, but I couldn't see much use for it on its own.
The nose is beautiful, hints of crème brûlée and almost a banana-type note. That all changed when I took a sip and the alcohol flavors took over

My preferred bourbon mixer. Has all of your classic bourbon notes (brown sugar, cinnamon and vanilla) leaning slightly spicy. Medium body with significant heat. Not super balanced but has complexity not seen under $20 and, as a mixer, that imbalance is corrected. Gets an unfair bad reputation!
A lovely tasting bourbon that is packed with flavour....One of the bottles that I always have in at all times.
Big on value maybe the new drinkable
Warming sensation. Don’t get to much flavor out of this one. Better chilled

I think this bourbon is judged way too critically and underrated. It's easy to sip, high proof, full of rich, pleasant flavors, widely available, and bang for the buck. You can mix it, spill it, throw it away on guests who care none for whiskey, and not feel much guilt or anger.

Nose of paint thinner or acetone but surprisingly not in an off-putting way. Further draws include dark cherry and caramel. Sip (with a splash of water) start very mild on the tip of the tongue with some mild burn in the center. Vanilla and cherry are strong. I don't get much brown sugar but the sweetness is obvious. Finishing with a mild smoke and French vanilla ice cream.
Not as much nite as I thought it would have. Uprising for the high proof. I immediately tasted cherry.
As my everyday, I hope it doesn’t become too popular where I cannot find it.
Underappreciated due to the Wild Turkey label. If you don't like it neat, try it over ice for a completely different experience. High quality to price ratio with this.
My go-to on a SW flight. Pretty good.
This is the best bang for your buck whiskey
The more I drink, the better it is. Or something like that. Decent.
Nutmeg, spice, oak, some cinnamon and citrus (strong and sharp palate) - a long finish of dry oak and alcohol burn (Kentucky hug)
Caramel aroma. Great oaky whiskey taste. Not overly sweet , but smooth
Hay, butterscotch, rye spice. My heart

Hot, butterscotch, peppery, but mostly sweet until a bitter citrus zest note toward the finish, which is nice. I like it a lot. Only Evan Williams bottled-in-bond is a better value for the quality, in my amateur opinion.
Oak, oak, and more oak. Nose also has some caramel & citrus, palate of random chocolate & creme brulee, and finish of brown sugar.
Aroma is great. I don’t love the taste. A little too harsh
At $25-26 this one is a definite buy.
Sweet vanilla and caramel with hint of spice and faint cherry on the nose. Spicy and woodsy on the palate
Simple but good. I enjoy the taste but it is not complex in anyway. It is more of a watching football type of bourbon, not a making memories with family or long lost friends type of bourbon
Straight foreword bourbon with a tad more rye and baking spices

Nose: Vanilla, Leather.
Pallet: Cherry, Oak, Vanilla Bean
Spicy hot peanutbutter, brown sugar, and oak.  This is what an entry bourbon should be.
Thick and warm, butter, caramel, brown sugar, cork (yes, cork), some good spice on the finish.  I like the 81 better for the thinner palate
Butterscotch, some heat from the abv, some caramel, some vanilla. Maybe cherry?
Nice warm finish.  Light nose.  Full flavor
Can’t be beat for the price.

Nose: Very strong vanilla notes.  Toasted oak
To a lesser degree. Does not have alcohol smell even when first poured.  

Palate: to be considered a “budget” bourbon it is full of flavor.  Caramel, oak, and cinnamon are the dominant flavors.  The mouthfeel is damn near perfect.  Coats the tongue nicely. 

Finish: medium finish of pepper and spice.  Have read reviews that say alcohol tastes resonates.  Not to me.  

I’ve probably rated this a little low at 3.25. Have tasted much higher rated (and pricier) bourbons that were not near as flavorful.  This would make a great daily drinker.

Bumping this one up to 3.5 stars as i'm really enjoying this for a $20 bourbon. I get a lot of notes from the Russell's Reserve in this but at a much nicer price point. I think the Wild Turkey products agree with my palate similar to the Elijah Craig products do.

Nose: sweet corn, vanilla and oak, brown sugar bomb
Palate: Caramel, vanilla, cherry wood, barrel char
Finish: long and spicy with lingering wood notes.

This is truly a hidden gem that gets put in the bottom shelf category. Its probably the best bourbon in its price range and will hold up with bourbon twice its price, you really can't go wrong with turkey. Over a 100 proof for less than $25 is a win.

Nose - brown sugar, honey, light cinnamon, butterscotch, corn, mild oak, cherry, maybe some chocolate undertones. 

Taste - sweet cinnamon, brown sugar, corn, vanilla, a bit of pepper, finishing oaky and mildly sweet.

Classic bourbon flavor. Excellent budget bourbon.
I get a lot of cherry and cinnamon on the nose. Dusty corn dominates on the taste. The finish is just a tad harsh. Not bad.
I love it always have always will although I will say the older stocks are better but it's still a phenomenal bourbon for 18 bucks
Solid pour.  Nice spice or burn on finish.
One of the more underrated bourbons on the market. Great butterscotch and vanilla flavors. Smooth for the perceived quality and price.

Nose- hard carmel / orange /oiled leather 
Taste- peppery / silky dark chocolate 
Finish - oily / fresh minty / fairly long

*neat with splash of water*

Nose: ethanol forward, some light smokiness and oak

Palate: about as smooth as you would expect for $20 bourbon, but its drinkable nonetheless.  I get some heavy oak and cherry overall. It tastes similar to a cherry cough syrup to me. Definitely a burn on the finish.

Overall, it's just ok for the price. I don't really get the hype on this, but it wasn't terrible. Could be a good mixer for a Manhattan since it is a high rye, but other than that I would always take BT or Jameson over it.
Love me some WT101. Great daily supper.

Vanilla and sweet on the nose, followed by harsher oak/spice/cinnamon and some expected alcohol burn on deep inhales.  
Palate has some nice sweet vanilla and caramel with citrus and tart oak coming on at the end.  Mouth feel is okay, nothing too special.
Impressively long rye spice finish with a little more oak and sweet shining through. Gets a little tart at the end however. 

In short: lots of flavors going on, but not well mingled or balanced.  The flavors compete and dominate depending on how you sip, rather than compliment each other. 

Good for the price, just sips a little too hot for an everyday. The proof point is solid, and leads to a nice long finish that can get a little hot and out of hand.  Could use a few more years, but definitely no complaints for $20. Probably prefer Buffalo Trace or OGD 114 at the same price point
Sweet and smooth but with just the right amount of spice. I can’t believe this bourbon is so good for so cheap. A great sipper but seems like it would hold up great in a cocktail also.
Very strong rich, spicy leather and sweet corn
A little bit of everything in huge amounts. A very full on bourbon with a lovely spice finish. Great value for money, considering the depth of flavours
What a great bourbon. Sweet cherry on the nose, slight nuttiness with hints of vanilla and wood. A splash of water makes everything more punchy.

Wild Turkey gets a bad rep but this right here is a quintessential bourbon...for better or worse. The nose greets you with a hint of burned caramel and wood, opening up with time to fragrances of cherry and a very slight herbal quality. The taste is where I'd say this stands out when compared to other budget Bourbons. Frankly, it's delicious, if not a little by the numbers. Classic brown sugar and vanilla notes mix beautifully with the barrel spice you'd expect out of a higher proof bourbon. Wild Turkey gets a bad rep but that's no reason to turn your nose up at this sub $30 daily drinker.
Pretty spiced but just lacks that mouth feel. It’s fine. Probably a great mixer too.

On the nose first alcohol varnish, then a sweet artificial fruity note on top, a bazooka bubblegum, with some caramel. There is a strong grain presence, that is unusual for me in Bourbon, however it is not overpowering like it could be (thinking of some new malt distilleries that haven't found their way yet). Vanilla.

Unlike many other Bourbons the palate entrance is not so sweet but bitter and tart, making way for more citrus acidity and then sweetness emerges. Woody and grainy. 

Texture is excellent. Oily mouthfill with some graininess. 

Finish is cinnamon and light ginger spice, and minty bitterness with chocolate notes. Long and slightly astringent.
For the price, it’s a good glass after a long day.
Butterscotch, vanilla creme brûlée. Nice spice, long oily finish.
Woody with warming spice. Sweet corn flavor, leathery mouth feel and aftertaste. Benefits from a few drops of water to balance out that strong oak. Good value.
Sweet with spice! Great complexity/bang for your buck.
Cinnamon on the nose with some gingerbread/molasses.  Flavors of dark cherries drizzled in chocolate.  There is a little umph from the alcohol and a slight barrel tannin.

Nose: Spicy leather and tobacco

Palate: sweet corn

Finish: sweet, but can’t tell what it is

Nose: floral, caramel, papaya, wood

Taste: super strong, caramel, butterscotch,woody

Aftertaste: short and very strong,woody

Follow me on insta: @whiskperience
It was good but not as good as redemption
Better than Jack, not quite as good as Buffalo Trace. Good well for the basement.
Strong, a bit of bite, mixer suggested

This is a very solid Bourbon. I have finally had the chance to try this higher proof offering from Wild Turkey. This is a very good Bourbon for $22 in my area and it is outstanding for the price. I tried this head to head with Evan Williams Bottled in Bond. While I prefer Evan Williams over Wild Turkey they are both very solid. Wild Turkey has a mild vanilla nose but the Oak jumps on you at the very beginning and is still there at the finish. However, there is a nice sweetness that shows up that mellows the Oak and makes it really nice. The overall flavor profile is just not me but it does mix well and with a little ice it is a good sipper. As I see it this is a solid addition to any bar and even if it does not fit your tastes exactly it is still good. So as I have space in my home bar I will try to have this in it. It is hard to go wrong with this Bourbon.
Sweet, with a charred, spicy finish.

Color is a nice gold. Lots of alcohol on the nose, fairly medicinal, some oak, vanilla. Taste is mildly sweet, cake, honey, lots of alcohol, "hot". Maybe some of that is spiciness, I'm not sure. That fades a bit, then more vanilla  honey.  Added a couple of drops of water, softens a bit but not really getting different notes.
Smooth for the proof. Burnt caramel, Light oak. No burn, warm afterglow. :) really like

A really tasty bourbon and one of my favorite budget options. That being said I’d definitely pay more for it because it’s darn good stuff. 

Nose - rye spice and baking spice up front, some caramel and nuttiness comes through as well
Taste - solid spice off the bat and the sweeter caramel notes come through, with a nice hint of milk chocolate with almonds
Finish - the spice lingers quickly but the heat remains, the sweeter caramel notes round things out
Very sweet on the nose. Fruity taste and sugary up front that definitely burns if allowed to linger. Incredible go to for a night on the back porch
Smooth for the percentage but not smoothest, wood oak spectrum of the bourbon flavor wheel
Spicy rye forward. Great in an Old Fashioned!
Mild grain flavor. Decently smooth. Mild sweetness

Famous for been an ingredient in barbecue sauces, this bourbon is a very solid offer for a low price, and i definitively recommend it.

Bottled at 50.5%abv, but so so sooooo smooth. 

On the nose, banana, bronzer (tanning cream), cinnamon and Vanilla. A very sweet bourbon on the nose.

On the palate, peppery, citric and very Mellowed. 

Finish long full of liquorice. Overall this is a fine dram, and i give it an 88 over 100. Really a fine offer for the price
One of my everyday drinkers. Can’t ask for much more. Price, taste, and 101 proof!

Yum! Shedding my cloak of whiskey ignorance and dipping my toe into this pool I once avoided (due to said ignorance!): 

Nose =  Oak, almost some butterscotch/caramel? Reaching but could argue cherry cordial

Palate =  Sweet, Caramel, could still argue cherry cordial or honey
Nice solid bourbon I always try and keep a handle of around. Great for cocktails or just straight
Classic. Amazing price to quality ratio.
Best value out there in my opinion

Great budget Bourbon! 
Aroma - boozey wood and vanilla / Taste - oak. and spice mixed with subtle orange / Finish - smoke and heat

Excellent value bourbon.  Mix of maple, caramel on the nose and a little bit of orange in the back section.  This whiskey is a solid contender for a "this should always be in my cabinet" contender.   I am a fan of whiskeys that don't need to be mixed with anything other than a little bit of water.  I enjoyed this thoroughly.
Pleasant, sweet aroma with an edge of alcohol. Strong caramels and vanilla on the palate. Finish is fairly short but not too harsh. Bourbon all the way.

A little woody, vanilla, crème brûlée on the palate. Spice and stone fruit on the finish. Little bit of water gives it a more viscuous mouthfeel and opens up toasted grain and dark chocolate notes. Tasty, and a steal for the price.
Spicy notes. Very smooth though so not too rough. A mellow evening drink

Poured neat. Initially notes of wood smoke, apple, and Sharpie. After resting for a few minutes, notes of brown sugar/caramel became more dominate, with a faint fruitiness. Taste reminded of warm apple pie with fruit and brown sugar notes carrying over, and the woody smell translated to a taste of a buttery pie crust. Going down of wasn't overly harsh, slight numbness on the tongue with light burn in throat that dissipated after a short time. Very enjoyable, especially for a newbie like myself.

On the nose, sweet caramel and vanilla. More aroma than I tend to find on Knob Creek 100. 

On the palette, it delivers the flavors you’d expect from the nose, with the addition of a slight chocolate note. 

During the finish, those same flavors continue and the chocolate becomes more dominant as the finish fades. 

Overall, decent flavor. Not something I’d choose as a go-to. However, it’s a flavorful medium-proof bourbon I’ll keep around for the rare-occasion mixed drink.

Buttery corn on the cob, salted caramel popcorn, old leather armchair, old parchment, sweet cherries, vanilla, musty wood on the nose. Spicy on the tongue, rich mid tones. Light smokey, slightly bitter woody long finish.
This spicy bourbon will always be in my cabinet. The only thing that tips it so far is Rare Breed.
A classic but somewhat harsh bourbon.
Carmel and vanilla noise.  Vanilla and good spice flavor.  Great bourbon for the price.

Good daily sipper. 
Smooth, good taste.
harsh, bold bourbon, with intensive wood, vanilla and chocolate notes. Great for anything - sipping (with a little water), shots or cocktails
Baking spice and cinnamon. Picked up a handle for $39
After trying this and a few other

Mostly rye spice on the nose but not overpowering. Slight vanilla and caramel but I’m not picking up fruits.

Palate is round and a little complex for the price point. Finish is rather short and heat lingers in throat.

Not bad for the price point, would likely pick over JD/JB due to the higher proof. 

I use the rating scale below. Distiller uses a scale of 5 and I use a scale of 10, but I’m sure you’re not too drunk to do the math! 

1. Disgusting - So bad I poured it out.
2. Poor - I wouldn't consume by choice.
3. Bad - Multiple flaws.
4. Below average - Not bad, but many things I'd rather have.
5. Good - Just average.
6. Very Good - Better than average.
7. Great - Well above average.
8. Excellent - In a league of its own.
9. Incredible - An all-time favorite.
10. Perfect

Imagine my surprise at having my first pour of Wild Turkey 101, a brand I had always assumed to be below average, and really enjoying my first bottle.

The nose is vanilla and oak, which rounds out to toffee and molasses at the swallow.

The burn is not insignificant, but it also doesn't scorch the palate. In fact, once you process the burn out of your nasal cavity, that bit of heat dovetails beautifully with the dry barrel char. 

The barrel spices come through as a combination of lemon pepper and orange rind. (I'm guessing that's the rye.) Also has a cinnamon component that adds a little prickle at the end.

The finish is a tannic pucker, which merges with an inky, metallic coda. I'm so pleased with this, and surprised by it's complexity, and it will have a regular presence on my shelf.
Rich vanilla notes! The higher proof is nice for a change too
Excellent whiskey for the price a favorite among millions  I enjoyed this quite a bit  perfect for an every day drinker. Planning to do a bib shootout with this , evan William's  and old grand dad

Neat. Neck pour.  I drink this a lot at restaurants and concerts but never had a bottle on my bar until now.  I love most Turkey products.  I had a Kentucky Spirit that was underwhelming for the price but other than that I tend to love it all.

Nose is delightful.  Deep, bready baking spices.  Nice vanilla coupled with burnt caramel.  Hint of cherry.  I’d venture to say this is the best nose on a $20 or less bourbon.  

Nice creamy texture.  Very light cinnamon sugar up front, transitions to the caramels and vanillas.  Rye really lingers on the back.

Such a good bourbon for the price.  The flavors are crisp but nothing over the top great.  Just solid through and through.  I would be good with this an as everyday drinker.

Healthy amount of ethanol on the nose along with butterscotch and vanilla.
The alcohol on the nose is readily apparent on the palate but touches of vanilla, cinnamon, and oak help round it out.
The finish lingers with a hearty burn. The spiciness overwhelms any sweetness that was on the palate.

Not a bad bourbon but not something I’d sip on neat which is my preference. It’d make for some great mixed drinks I’m sure.

Nose: spice and caramel and cherry

Palate: kinda bitter flavor and a lot of spice up front. No fruit or anything. Black pepper, typical with the wild turkeys I’ve had 

Finish: more black pepper and rye
Nice with touch of water. Lots of character.  Sipping with ice.
This is a very nice bourbon, over ice with a little water, lovely bouquet, and a very nice palate. I have always been a Jim Beam lover, but this beats JB.
I love the vanilla/caramel sweetness contrasted with the peppery/charred oak spiciness. Great for the price!

For the price, possibly the best widely available bourbon. Full, rich, a bit of barrel spice, not too sweet. Everything you could ever ask out of a budget bourbon, plus some. Also, it’s 101 proof. That can’t hurt.

“Standard” bourbon vanilla and caramel on the nose. Followed by the same standard flavors, a bit of ethanol, and some cinnamon. Finish hangs on at 101 proof, and holds with a cinnamon baking spice flavor.

Nose- caramel and stinging smell of alcohol 

Taste- caramel to start then leveling to a sweet with the alcohol present at all times. At times it is slightly harsh, but overall not bad. The spice of the whiskey gives way to a Sweet aftertaste that mellows into notes of apricot and vanilla.


Overall- as a budget whiskey it is a powerful whiskey worthy of being an “everyday driver” of any collection. While it won’t compete with its finer bred brethren, it suffices as on its own and the drinker will be stronger because of it.
Nice amount of Rye character, and a good bang for your buck bottle.

For an upstate weekend, I usually bring a bottle of something this can be found at an affordable price, is a departure from Jack Daniels (that is the staple whiskey that my good friend drinks) so I can expand horizons as well as we can drink over laughs.  I grabbed a 1 liter bottle of the 101 as this seemed to fit the bill this particular long weekend.  I peeled off for a  moment to do a tasting before I get back to more food and laughs. 

A light and airy nose with dense balanced aromas of vanilla, butterscotch and baking spices. As it breathes and opens, clover honey, Luxardo cherries and lemon zest add to the vanilla and baking spices, all which seem to push to the forward.

Lightly toasted marble rye bread spread with vanilla-honey, drizzled with caramel starts the palate. Toasted coconut adds a touch tropical influence. This all sounds overly sweet, but the sweetness is held in check by barrel spice and baking spices of cinnamon, nutmeg and cloves.  The texture is creamy with a medium weight density.

With some water, the spicy edginess is smoothed out and the dynamic of sweetness to spice is lessened; the extremes become more harmonious.  Water is recommended as it becomes a better dram. 

Spearmint and dill ride a medium length finish with barrel charcoal, vanilla and white pepper. 

When you drink this as a quick banger, it can be course and edgy.  However, if you slow down, tame it, it will bring you down a path that is tasty, enjoyable and rewarding.  I was pleasantly surprised that for a $30 liter whiskey can actually be a good sipper and bring a simple, rewarding pleasure.  Thanks @dubz480 for confirming this as a solid choice for the parameters earlier mentioned. [85/100][Tasted: 6/13/20]
Baking spice, caramel, vanilla, rich and balanced
Pretty standard bourbon. Lots of corn and new barrel roughness. A bit of water tones it down. Still just a pretty good bourbon.
It’s ok. Nothing to write home about but would definitely drink again
